TEXT.French: Cadre de la Banque de St George
TEXT.German: Gesandter der Bank von St. George
TEXT.Italian: Dirigente di Banca di San Giorgio
TEXT.Spanish: Mercader del Banco de S. Jorge

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Poor Fellow-Soldiers of Christ and of the Temple of Solomon (Latin: Pauperes Commilitones Christi Templique Solomonice), commonly known as the Knights Templar or the Order of the Temple, were among the most famous of the Western Christian military orders. The organizaton existed for approximately two centuries in the Middle Ages. It was founded in the aftermath of the First Crusade of 1096 to ensure the safety of the many Europeans who made the pilgrimage to Jerusalem after its conquest.
TEXT.French: Le pauvre enfant-soldats du Christ et du Temple de Salomon (en latin: Pauperes commilitones Christi Templique Solomonice), communément appelé l'Ordre du Temple ou de l'Ordre du Temple, furent parmi les plus célèbres de l'ordre chrétien occidental militaire. Cette Organisation existe depuis environ deux siècles dans le Moyen Age. Elle a été fondée au lendemain de la première croisade de 1096 pour assurer la sécurité des nombreux Européens qui ont fait le pèlerinage à Jérusalem après sa conquête.

TEXT.English: [TAB] In 1143 Pope Celestine II ordered the Knight Hospitaller to take over management of a German Hospital in Jerusalem, which, according to the chronicler Jean d'Ypres, accommodated the countless German pilgrims and crusaders who could neither speak the local tongue (i.e.French) no Latin (patrie linguam ignorantibus atque Latinam). However although formally an institution of the Hospitallers, the Pope commanded that the prior and the brothers of the domus Teutonicorum (house of the Germans) should always be Germans themselves,so a tradition of a German-led religious institution could develop during the 12th century in Palestine.
TEXT.French: En 1143, le Pape Célestin II ordonna l'Ordre Hospitalier, pour reprendre la gestion d'un hôpital allemand à Jérusalem, qui, selon le chroniqueur Jean d'Ypres, accueilli les innombrables pèlerins et les croisés allemands qui ne pouvait ni parler la langue locale n i le Latin. Toutefois, bien que formellement une institution des Hospitaliers, le Pape ordonna que le prieur et les frères de la Teutonicorum domus (maison des Allemands) doit toujours être Allemands eux-mêmes, donc une tradition d'une conduite par l'Allemagne institution religieuse pourrait se développer pendant le 12ème siècle en Palestine.

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Knights Hospitaller (also known as the Sovereign Military Hospitaller, Order of St. John of Jerusalem of Rhodos and of Malta, Knights of Malta, Knights of Rhodos and Chevaliers of Malta) is a Christian organization that began as an Amalfitan hospital founded in Jerusalem in 1080 to provide care for poor and sick pilgrims to the Holy Land. After the Christian conquest of Jerusalem in 1099 during the First Crusade it became a religious/military order under its own charter, and was charged with the care and defense of the Holy Land. Following the loss of the Holy Land by Christan forces, the Order operated from Rhodos, over which it was sovereign, and later from Malta where it administered a vassal state under the Spanish viceroy of Sicily.
TEXT.French: Hospitaliers Chevaliers (également connu sous le Souverain Militaire Hospitalier de l'Ordre de Saint Jean de Jérusalem de Rhodes et de Malte, les Chevaliers de Malte, les Chevaliers de Rhodes et Chevaliers de Malte) est une organisation chrétienne qui a commencé comme un hôpital d'Amalfi fondé à Jérusalem en 1080 pour fournir des soins pour les pèlerins pauvres et des malades vers la Terre Sainte. Après la conquête chrétienne de Jérusalem en 1099 pendant la première croisade, il est devenu un ordre religieux-militaire en vertu de sa propre charte, et a été chargé du soin et la défense de la Terre Sainte. Après la perte de la Terre Sainte par les forces de Christan, l'Ordre exploité depuis Rhodes, sur laquelle elle est souveraine, et plus tard en provenance de Malte où il a géré un Etat vassal en vertu de la vice-roi espagnol de la Sicile.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Hanseatic League was an alliance of trading cities, which estabilshed a trade monopoly across both the Baltic and the North Seas, as well as riverside cities in Northern Europe. The alliance was involved, apart from trading, in and political issues. It was founded at Lubeck at the 12th century, and managed to expand at Eastern Europe. Actually, it played a crucial role in the germanization of this area, founding outposts such as Reval and Elbing. Its fall is placed at the 16th century, due to internal clashes, and rise of other trading powers, such as the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark.

[TAB]The Medici Bank was the largest and most highly reputated bank in Europe, spanning from 1397 to 1494 Its founders, the Medici family, was one of the richest families in Europe, and later they used their wealth to acquire political power in their homeland, Florence. They actually became a corporation after branches of the bank were spread in other Italian cities (Venice, Milano, Rome), as well as important trading centers outside Italy (London, Avignon, Brugge). The Medici managed to control the clothing production, apart from banking duties, thus managing to make extra profit. The reasons for the banks' decline include Lorenzo Medici's disconcern for the bank and the French invasion to Italy 1497.

[TAB]At late Medieval/early Rennaisance years, the city of Augsburg became an important economic and trading center. Thus, the conditions for the creation of a mercantile patriciate were perfect. Prominent merchant families in this era, based in Augsburg, were the Fugger, the Hoechstetter and the Welser families. Activities of these families included trading and banking. In specific, the Hoechstretters built their wealth by controlling the iron ore deposits in the eastern provinces of HRE (Silesia, Bohemia), the Welsers by exploiting the German colonization of the Americas and the Fuggers by involving in the political scene of Augsburg.

[TAB]The Bank of St George was a financial institution of the Genoan Republic. It was founded at 1407, and was governed by four consuls. The Bank did not only have economic power, but was involved at the politics of Genoa, due to the merchants' role in running the Republic of Genoa. In fact, the Bank controlled many of the Genoans' overseas territories, including Corsica. It gained reputation in 15th an 16th centuries, when prominent European Leaders (including Isabella of Spain) had accounts there. Later, it antagonized the Dutch and English East India Companies in maritime trading. It was closed by Napoleon in 1805.
[ICON_BULLET]Can only be founded in coastal town.
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Can only be founded in coastal town.
TEXT.German: [ICON_BULLET]Kann nur in einer Küstestadt gegründet werden.
TEXT.Italian: [ICON_BULLET]Can only be founded in coastal town.
TEXT.Spanish: [ICON_BULLET]Can only be founded in coastal town.
